newsitem.title: USA: Bond-financed Indianapolis mall turns one year old.
newsitem.headline: Bond-financed Indianapolis mall turns one year old.

text.p: A partially bond-financed retail mall in downtown Indianapolis celebrates its one-year anniversary Sunday and indications are that the project has been a success.
"We feel very good and the mall is doing what it's suppose to do," said Jim Snyder, special council to Indianapolis Mayor Steve Goldsmith.

What the Circle Centre mall has done, according to Snyder, is help attract other development to the city's downtown. So far, the list includes a number of hotels, restaurants and a recently announced new office building, he said.

Indianapolis Local Public Improvement Bond Bank sold tax increment financing bonds, secured by the city's moral obligation pledge, in 1988 to help build the mall. However, numerous delays, including a sluggish retail climate, a property tax dispute within the TIF district, and the mall developer's problem obtaining his share of the financing, pushed back the original 1991 opening to 1995.
In 1992, even though the mall was still just a bunch of holes in the ground, the bond bank refinanced $290 million of bonds.

Snyder, who is also executive director of the bond bank, said that revenues from property taxes within the 150-square block TIF district in downtown Indianapolis backing the bonds, are running $1 million to $1.5 million a year over estimates.
Richard Raphael, executive managing director at Fitch Investors Service, said he was glad to see the mall project worked out well.
"It's very central to the city's (downtown) development efforts," he said.
Fitch rates the TIF bonds AA. Analysts at Standard & Poor's Corp., which rates the debt A-plus, were not available to comment.
The 800,000-square-foot mall is 97 percent leased and has annualized sales of $400 per square foot, according to a news release from the mall.
